sen.j: 淀古城（よど こじょう）は京都府京都市伏見区納所北城堀にあった城。
sen.e: The Yodo kojo Castle is a castle which was located at Noso Kitashirobori, Fushimi Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
The Yodo kojo Castle is a castle which was located at Noso Kitashirobori, Fushimi Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
The Yodo kojo Castle is a castle which was located at Noso Kitashirobori, Fushimi Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: 納所は木津川 (京都府)・桂川 (淀川水系)・瀬田川の三川が合流するポイントの北岸にあたりに築城され、三面を川に囲まれた天然の要害で、古くからの商業地「淀」の中核都市であった。
sen.e: Noso, located at the northern shore of the confluence of three rivers, Kizu-gawa River (Kyoto Prefecture), Katsura-gawa River (Yodo-gawa River system) and Seta-gawa River, where the castle was built and which was natural fort surrounded by rivers on three sides, was a major urban area of the old commercial district, 'Yodo.'

Noso, located at the northern shore of the confluence of three rivers, Kizu-gawa River (Kyoto Prefecture), Katsura-gawa River (Yodo-gawa River system) and Seta-gawa River, where the castle was built and which was a natural fort surrounded by rivers on three sides, was a major urban area of the old commercial district, 'Yodo.'

Noso, located at the northern shore of the confluence of three rivers, Kizu-gawa River (Kyoto Prefecture), Katsura-gawa River (Yodo-gawa River system) and Seta-gawa River, where the castle was built and which was a natural fort surrounded by rivers on three sides, was a major urban area of the old commercial district, 'Yodo.'

sen.j: この城の文献上初見は『東院年中行事』の文明 (日本)10年（1478年）8月1日で、以下のように山城国の守護所として記されている。
sen.e: The first appearance of this castle was on August 1, 1478 in the "Annual events of Higashi no in"
The first appearance of this castle was on August 1, 1478 in the "Annual events of Higashi no in"

This castle was first mentioned in a historical document on August 1, 1478 in the "Annual events of Higashi no in," in which the following comment concerning the Shugosho (provincial administration) of the Province of Yamashiro was made:
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に変更しました。→書物の中の年月日なのでそのままにしました。セル11から「以下のように山城国の守護所として記されている。」を追加しました。

sen.j: 山城守護代遊佐弾正の代（中略）神保与三佐衛門淀へ入部す
sen.e: Yosazaemon JINBO entered Yodo...during the era of the Danjo YUSA Yamashiro no Shugodai (deputy of the Shugo, or provincial constable, of Yamashiro Province).
sen.cmt: ウィキペディアの「淀古城」より、原文欠落部を赤字で挿入しました。遊佐弾正の読み方は不明ですが、訳をつけました。

sen.j: 畠山政長守護が応仁の乱に西軍の畠山義就に備えるため、守護所を勝竜寺から当城に移したのではないかと思われている。
sen.e: Shugo (provincial constable), Masanaga HATAKEYAMA is thought to have moved Shugosho from Shoryu-ji Temple to this castle during Onin War to brace for possible attacks by Yoshinari HATAKEYAMA of West squad.

Shugo (provincial constable), Masanaga HATAKEYAMA is thought to have moved Shugosho from Shoryu-ji Temple to this castle during the Onin War to brace for possible attacks by Yoshinari HATAKEYAMA of the West squad.

Shugo (provincial constable), Masanaga HATAKEYAMA is thought to have moved Shugosho from Shoryu-ji Temple to this castle during the Onin War to brace for possible attacks by Yoshinari HATAKEYAMA of the West squad.

sen.j: その後以降に細川氏京兆家が山城国を掌握すると守護代級の被官によって守衛され、摂津国、河内国の抑えの城として使用されてきた。
sen.e: Afterward, when Hosokawa Keicho family came to control the Province of Yamashiro, the castle was guarded by Shugodai (deputy of Shugo, provincial constable)-level Hikan (low-level bureaucrat) and used to watch Settsu Province and Kawachi Province.

Afterward, when the Hosokawa Keicho family came to control the Province of Yamashiro, the castle was guarded by Shugodai (deputy of Shugo, provincial constable)-level Hikan (low-level bureaucrat) and used to watch Settsu Province and Kawachi Province.

Afterward, when the Hosokawa Keicho family came to control the Province of Yamashiro, the castle was guarded by Shugodai (deputy of Shugo, provincial constable)-level Hikan (low-level bureaucrat) and used to watch Settsu Province and Kawachi Province.

sen.j: 第一次淀古城の戦い
sen.e: First Battle of Yodokojo
First Battle of Yodokojo
First Battle of Yodokojo

sen.j: 1504年（永正元年）に入ると赤沢朝経と細川政元が対立するようになる。
sen.e: started, then Tomotsune AKAZAWA and Masamoto HOSOKAWA came to be opposed to each other.
sen.cmt: 「に入ると」の前に欠落があるように思います。とりあえず、何かが始まるというニュアンスで、「started」としました。
sen.e: started, then Tomotsune AKAZAWA and Masamoto HOSOKAWA came to be opposed to each other.
In 1504, Tomotsune AKAZAWA and Masamoto HOSOKAWA came to be opposed to each other.
sen.cmt: 年号をウェブから補いました（本文は赤字）。一部、翻訳を変更しました。

sen.j: 細川政元は同年3月9日摂津国守護代の薬師寺元一に槇島城に攻城戦するように命じたが、赤沢朝経軍は600-700兵を従えて城から撤兵したようである。
sen.e: Masamoto HOSOKAWA, on March 9, 0000 ordered Motokazu YAKUSHIJI, a deputy shugo of the Province of Settsu to attack the Makishima-jo Castle, but the Tomotsune AKAZAWA's army seemed to leave the castle with 600-700 soldiers.
sen.cmt: 「同年」の年代不明のため、「0000」としました。
sen.e: Masamoto HOSOKAWA, on March 9, 0000 ordered Motokazu YAKUSHIJI, a deputy shugo of the Province of Settsu to attack Makishima-jo Castle, but Tomotsune AKAZAWA's army seemed to leave the castle with 600-700 soldiers.

Masamoto HOSOKAWA, on April 4, 1504 ordered Motokazu YAKUSHIJI, a deputy shugo of the Province of Settsu to attack Makishima-jo Castle, but Tomotsune AKAZAWA's army seemed to leave the castle with 600-700 soldiers.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に変更しました。

sen.j: それを知った畠山尚順軍は槇島城と並び交通、軍事の要所であった淀古城を攻城してきた。
sen.e: Hisanobu HATAKEYAMA came to know it and his army attacked the Yodo kojo Castle which was a key place for transportation and military as the Makishima-jo Castle was.
Hisanobu HATAKEYAMA came to know this and his army attacked Yodo kojo Castle which was a key place for transportation and military, just as Makishima-jo Castle was.
Hisanobu HATAKEYAMA came to know this and his army attacked Yodo kojo Castle which was a key place for transportation and military, just as Makishima-jo Castle was.

sen.j: 細川政元軍は神保与三佐衛門を城主としていたようだが、薬師寺元一、薬師寺長忠兄弟、香西元長、内藤氏内藤氏（丹波系）軍も入城させ、畠山尚順軍からの攻城戦に備えた。
sen.e: The Masamoto HOSOKAWA's army seemed to keep Yosazaemon JINBO as Joshu (castellan), but braced for possible attacks by the Hisanobu HATAKEYAMA's army making the armies of Motokazu YAKUSHIJI and Nagatada YAKUSHIJI brothers, Motonaga KOZAI and Naito clan (Tanba) enter the castle.

Masamoto HOSOKAWA's army seemed to keep Yosazaemon JINBO as Joshu (castellan), but braced for possible attacks by Hisanobu HATAKEYAMA's army making the armies of Motokazu YAKUSHIJI and Nagatada YAKUSHIJI brothers, and Motonaga KOZAI and the Naito clan (Tanba) enter the castle.

Masamoto HOSOKAWA's army seemed to keep Yosazaemon JINBO as Joshu (castellan), but braced for possible attacks by Hisanobu HATAKEYAMA's army making the armies of Motokazu YAKUSHIJI and Nagatada YAKUSHIJI brothers, and Motonaga KOZAI and the Naito clan (Tanba line) enter the castle.
sen.cmt: Tanbaの後にlineを挿入しました。

sen.j: この時別の局面が展開される。
sen.e: Then, another situation was developed.
Then, another situation was developed.
Then, another situation was developed.

sen.j: 細川政元軍に属していた薬師寺元一が細川澄元を擁立し、細川政元に謀反を仕掛けた。
sen.e: Motokazu YAKUSHIJI, who belonged to the Masamoto HOSOKAWA's army rose in rebellion against Masamoto HOSOKAWA by backing up Sumimoto HOSOKAWA.
Motokazu YAKUSHIJI, who belonged to Masamoto HOSOKAWA's army, rose up in rebellion against Masamoto HOSOKAWA by backing Sumimoto HOSOKAWA.
Motokazu YAKUSHIJI, who belonged to Masamoto HOSOKAWA's army, rose up in rebellion against Masamoto HOSOKAWA by backing Sumimoto HOSOKAWA.

sen.j: これに呼応した山城国の国人衆と槇島城から赤沢朝経軍が援軍として淀古城に籠もった。
sen.e: An army of the Kokujin-shu (local samurais) of the Yamashiro Province and the Tomotsune AKAZAWA' army from the Makishima-jo Castle, in cooperation, held the Yodo kojo Castle as a reinforcement.
An army of the Kokujin-shu (local samurais) of Yamashiro Province and Tomotsune AKAZAWA' army from Makishima-jo Castle, in cooperation, held Yodo kojo Castle as a reinforcement.
An army of the Kokujin-shu (local samurais) of Yamashiro Province and Tomotsune AKAZAWA' army from Makishima-jo Castle, in cooperation, kept to Yodo kojo Castle.
sen.cmt: 一部、翻訳を変更しました。

sen.j: しかし薬師寺元一の弟、薬師寺長忠は細川政元軍に属したまま兄と袂を分かつことになる。
sen.e: However, Nagatada YAKUSHIJI, a younger brother of Motokazu YAKUSHIJI, remaining belonged to the Masamoto HOSOKAWA's army, came to split with his elder brother.
However, Nagatada YAKUSHIJI, a younger brother of Motokazu YAKUSHIJI, remaining in Masamoto HOSOKAWA's army, came to split with his elder brother.
However, Nagatada YAKUSHIJI, a younger brother of Motokazu YAKUSHIJI, remaining in Masamoto HOSOKAWA's army, came to split with his elder brother.

sen.j: 薬師寺長忠、香西元長は淀古城を攻城し細川政元軍の手に落ちた。
sen.e: Nagatada YAKUSHIJI and Motonaga KOZAI attacked the Yodo kojo Castle, but fell into the hands of the Masamoto HOSOKAWA's army.
Nagatada YAKUSHIJI and Motonaga KOZAI attacked Yodo kojo Castle, but fell into the hands of Masamoto HOSOKAWA's army.
Nagatada YAKUSHIJI and Motonaga KOZAI attacked Yodo kojo Castle, but fell into the hands of Masamoto HOSOKAWA's army.

sen.j: 淀古城に籠もっていた四宮長能は自害、薬師寺元一は捕えられ同年9月20日京で自害、赤沢朝経は大和国へ敗走していった。
sen.e: Nagayoshi SHINOMIYA who held the Yodo kojo Castle committed suicide, Motokazu YAKUSHIJI was captured and committed suicide in Kyoto on September 20, 0000 and Tomotsune AKAZAWA took flight to the Yamato Province.
sen.cmt: 「同年」の年代不明のため、「0000」としました。
sen.e: Nagayoshi SHINOMIYA, who held Yodo kojo Castle, committed suicide, and Motokazu YAKUSHIJI was captured and committed suicide in Kyoto on September 20, 0000 and Tomotsune AKAZAWA took flight to Yamato Province.

Nagayoshi SHINOMIYA, who held Yodo kojo Castle, committed suicide, and Motokazu YAKUSHIJI was captured and committed suicide in Kyoto on November 6, 1504 and Tomotsune AKAZAWA took flight to Yamato Province.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に変更しました。

sen.j: この戦いが契機となり、細川氏との対立が本格化し山城国、河内国、和泉国、摂津国、大和国に戦線が拡大していく。
sen.e: Due to this battle, its opposition to the Hosokawa family gained momentum and the battle lines extended to the Provinces of Yamashiro, Kawachi, Izumi, Settsu and Yamato.
Due to this battle, its opposition to the Hosokawa family gained momentum and the battle lines extended to the Provinces of Yamashiro, Kawachi, Izumi, Settsu and Yamato.
Due to this battle, its opposition to the Hosokawa family gained momentum and the battle lines extended to the Provinces of Yamashiro, Kawachi, Izumi, Settsu and Yamato.

sen.j: この戦いでは細川政元軍に属して薬師寺長忠、香西元長であったが、2年後の永正の錯乱では、兄が擁立していた細川澄元を自身が擁立し細川政元の暗殺に成功する。
sen.e: Although Nagatada YAKUSHIJI and Motonaga KOZAI belonged to the Masamoto HOSOKAWA's army in this battle, Nagatada, 2 years later in Eisho no Sakuran (Disturbance), backed up Sumimoto HOSOKAWA who his brother backed up and succeeded in assassination of Masamoto HOSOKAWA.

Although Nagatada YAKUSHIJI and Motonaga KOZAI belonged to Masamoto HOSOKAWA's army in this battle, Nagatada, 2 years later in the Eisho no Sakuran (Disturbance), backed up Sumimoto HOSOKAWA, who his brother backed up, and succeeded in the assassination of Masamoto HOSOKAWA.

Although Nagatada YAKUSHIJI and Motonaga KOZAI belonged to Masamoto HOSOKAWA's army in this battle, Nagatada, 2 years later in the Eisho no Sakuran (Disturbance), backed up Sumimoto HOSOKAWA, who his brother backed up, and succeeded in the assassination of Masamoto HOSOKAWA.

sen.j: その後細川氏の被官が代々淀古城を治めていたが、細川政権 (戦国時代)から三好政権に移っていき、1559(永禄2年）には三好長慶が京を統一すると淀古城も細川氏綱が城主となったが、1563(永禄6年）にその細川氏綱も死去すると、三好義継が城主となり、ついで松永久秀方の武将が城主となったようである。
sen.e: After that, the Yodo kojo Castle was successively governed by Hikan of the Hosokawa family, but the control was gradually transferred from the Hosokawa's government (the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States)) to the Miyoshi's government and when Nagayoshi MIYOSHI unified Kyoto in 0000, Ujitsuna HOSOKAWA became the Joshu (castellan) of the Yodo kojo Castle, and upon the death of Ujitsuna HOSOKAWA, Yoshitsugu MIYOSHI succeeded him, and subsequently a Busho (Japanese military commander) belonged to Hisahide MATSUNAGA seemed to govern the castle.
sen.cmt: 「には三好長慶が京を統一すると」は、年代が欠落しているようなので、「in 0000」としました。
sen.e: After that, Yodo kojo Castle was successively governed by Hikan of the Hosokawa family, but control was gradually transferred from the Hosokawa's government (Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States)) to Miyoshi's government and when Nagayoshi MIYOSHI unified Kyoto in 0000, Ujitsuna HOSOKAWA became the Joshu (castellan) of Yodo kojo Castle, and upon the death of Ujitsuna HOSOKAWA, Yoshitsugu MIYOSHI succeeded him, and subsequently a Busho (Japanese military commander) belonging to Hisahide MATSUNAGA appeared to govern the castle.

After that, Yodo kojo Castle was successively governed by Hikan of the Hosokawa family, but control was gradually transferred from the Hosokawa's government (Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States)) to Miyoshi's government and when Nagayoshi MIYOSHI unified Kyoto in 1559, Ujitsuna HOSOKAWA became the Joshu (castellan) of Yodo kojo Castle, and upon the death of Ujitsuna HOSOKAWA in 1563, Yoshitsugu MIYOSHI succeeded him, and subsequently a Busho (Japanese military commander) belonging to Hisahide MATSUNAGA appeared to govern the castle.
sen.cmt: 年号をウェブから補いました（本文は赤字）。訳も年号を補いました。

sen.j: しかし永禄9年（1566年）7月に勝竜寺城と共に三好三人衆軍に攻城されると、三好長逸方の金子某が城主となったようである。
sen.e: However, in July 1566, it was, together with the Shoryuji-jo Castle, attacked by the army of the Miyoshi sanninshu (three chief retainers of the Miyoshi clan), then So-and-so KANEKO belonged to Nagayuki MIYOSHI seemed to become the castellan.

However, in July 1566, it was, together with the Shoryuji-jo Castle, attacked by the army of the Miyoshi sanninshu (three chief retainers of the Miyoshi clan), then So-and-so KANEKO belonged to Nagayuki MIYOSHI who seemed to become the castellan.
sen.cmt: slight modification赤いことばはおかしいと思われます。
sen.e: However, in July 1566, together with the Shoryuji-jo Castle, it was attacked by the army of the Miyoshi sanninshu (three chief retainers of the Miyoshi clan), then a certain KANEKO who belonged to Nagayuki MIYOSHI seemed to become the castellan.
sen.cmt: 一部、翻訳を変更しました。

sen.j: に織田信長が上洛を果たすと淀古城も織田信長軍の焼き討ちにあい落城してしまう。
sen.e: In 1568, Nobunaga ODA successfully went to the capital (Kyoto), then the Yodo kojo Castle fell in the fire attack by the Nobunaga ODA's army.
sen.cmt: 「に織田信長が」の前に年号「1568」を補足いたしました。出典（広辞苑第六版）
sen.e: In 1568, Nobunaga ODA successfully went to the capital (Kyoto), then Yodo kojo Castle fell in the fire attack by Nobunaga ODA's army.
In 1568, Nobunaga ODA successfully went to the capital (Kyoto), then Yodo kojo Castle fell in the fire attacked by Nobunaga ODA's army.

sen.j: 第二次淀古城の戦い
sen.e: Second Battle of Yodokojo
Second Battle of Yodokojo
Second Battle of Yodokojo

sen.j: 天正元年（1573年）2月に、征夷大将軍足利義昭は反織田信長を決意し、二条城で兵をあげた。
sen.e: In February 1573, Seitaishogun (commander-in-chief of the expeditionary force against the barbarians, great, unifying leader) Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA made up his mind to oppose Nobunaga ODA and rose up in arms in Nijo-jo Castle.

In February 1573, Seitaishogun (commander-in-chief of the expeditionary force against the barbarians, great, unifying leader) Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA made up his mind to oppose Nobunaga ODA and rose up in arms in Nijo-jo Castle.
In March 1573, Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA made up his mind to oppose Nobunaga ODA and rose up in arms in Nijo-jo Castle.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に変換しました。Seitaishogunを Seiitaishogunに変更しました。統一リストよりSeiitaishogun (commander-in-chief of the expeditionary force against the barbarians, great, unifying leader)→Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians")に変更しました。

sen.j: しかし、織田信長の動きも素早く岐阜城を出立、二条城を攻囲した。
sen.e: However, Nobunaga ODA acted swiftly, left the Gifu-jo Castle and besieged the Nijo-jo Castle.
However, Nobunaga ODA acted swiftly, left Gifu-jo Castle and besieged Nijo-jo Castle.
However, Nobunaga ODA acted swiftly, left Gifu-jo Castle and besieged Nijo-jo Castle.

sen.j: この時天皇の勧告により二条城を織田信長に明け渡したが、同年7月に槇島城に籠もり再び織田信長討伐の兵を挙げた。
sen.e: At the time, he yielded up the NIjo-jo Castle to Nobunaga ODA following the recommendation of the Emperor, but in July 1573, he again rose in arms to put down Nobunaga ODA entrenching themselves in the Makishima-jo Castle.

At the time, he yielded up Nijo-jo Castle to Nobunaga ODA following the recommendation of the Emperor, but in July 1573, he again rose in arms to put down Nobunaga ODA, entrenching themselves in Makishima-jo Castle.

At the time, he yielded up Nijo-jo Castle to Nobunaga ODA following the recommendation of the Emperor, but in September 1573, he again rose in arms to put down Nobunaga ODA, entrenching themselves in Makishima-jo Castle.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に変換しました。

sen.j: 足利義昭の要請に応じたのが三好三人衆の岩成友通で、淀古城に立て篭もったが、槇島城が織田信長軍に攻城され（槇島城の戦い）、足利義昭は二人の質子を入れ降伏し河内国に逃亡した。
sen.e: Tomomichi IWANARI, one of the Sanninshu acceded to Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA's request and entrenched himself in the Yodo kojo Castle, but the Makishima-jo Castle was attacked by the Nobunaga ODA's army (the Battle of the Makishima-jo Castle) and Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA surrendered with two hostages being given, then ran away to the Kawachi Province.
sen.cmt: 「質子」は、「広辞苑」、ウェブサイトにも見つからず、「人質」と解釈し、「hostages」としました。
sen.e: Tomomichi IWANARI, one of the Sanninshu acceded to Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA's request and entrenched himself in Yodo kojo Castle, but Makishima-jo Castle was attacked by Nobunaga ODA's army (Battle of Makishima-jo Castle) and Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA surrendered with two hostages being given, then ran away to Kawachi Province.

Tomomichi IWANARI, one of the Sanninshu acceded to Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA's request and entrenched himself in Yodo kojo Castle, but Makishima-jo Castle was attacked by Nobunaga ODA's army (Battle of Makishima-jo Castle) and Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA surrendered two hostages, then ran away to Kawachi Province.
sen.cmt: 一部、翻訳を変更しました。

sen.j: 一方淀古城に立て篭もる岩成友通隊に対しては、木下秀吉隊が対した。
sen.e: On the other hand, against the Tomomichi IWANARI's squad which held the Yodo kojo Castle, Hideyoshi KINOSHITA countered.
On the other hand, against Tomomichi IWANARI's squad,which held Yodo kojo Castle, Hideyoshi KINOSHITA countered.
On the other hand, against Tomomichi IWANARI's squad, which held Yodo kojo Castle, Hideyoshi KINOSHITA countered.
sen.cmt: squad,の後にスペースを挿入しました。

sen.j: 木下秀吉は計略を巡らし淀古城の城番頭大炊頭、諏訪三將らを味方につけた。
sen.e: Hideyoshi KINOSHITA worked out plans and bring over his side Mitsumasa SUWA, Head of the guards and Chief storekeeper and others of the Yodo kojo Castle.
sen.cmt: 「Mitsumasa SUWA」は、仮訳です。「城番頭大炊頭」を「head of the guards and kitchens manager」と訳しましたが、仮訳です。
sen.e: Hideyoshi KINOSHITA worked out plans and brought over to his side Mitsumasa SUWA, Head of the guards and Chief storekeeper and others of Yodo kojo Castle.
Hideyoshi KINOSHITA worked out plans and brought over to his side Mitsumasa SUWA, Head of the guards and Chief storekeeper and others of Yodo kojo Castle.

sen.j: 更に織田信長は近隣の勝竜寺城城主細川藤賢に出軍を命じ攻城軍に加わった。
sen.e: Further, Nobunaga ODA ordered the castellan of the Shoryuji-jo Castle, Fujikata HOSOKAWA to go to the front, and joined the attacking army.
Further, Nobunaga ODA ordered the castellan of Shoryuji-jo Castle, Fujikata HOSOKAWA to go to the front, and joined the attacking army.
Further, Nobunaga ODA ordered the castellan of Shoryuji-jo Castle, Fujikata HOSOKAWA to go to the front, and joined the attacking army.

sen.j: これに対応するため岩成友通は淀古城を出軍し奮戦したようである。
sen.e: To cope with this, Tomomichi IWANARI seemed to fight bravely leaving the Yodo kojo Castle.
To cope with this, Tomomichi IWANARI seemed to fight bravely leaving Yodo kojo Castle.
To cope with this, Tomomichi IWANARI seemed to fight bravely leaving Yodo kojo Castle.

sen.j: 防御施設が整っている城からわざわざ討って出たのは、大炊頭、諏訪三將らが強く進言したためと言われている。
sen.e: The reason why he dared to leave the castle well-equipped with defense facilities is said to be due to the strong recommendation by the Chief storekeeper, Mitsumasa SUWA and others.
The reason why he dared to leave the castle well-equipped with defense facilities is said to be due to the strong recommendation by the Chief storekeeper, Mitsumasa SUWA and others.
The reason why he dared to leave the castle well-equipped with defense facilities is said to be due to the strong recommendation by the Chief storekeeper, Mitsumasa SUWA and others.

sen.j: 岩成友通は奮戦したが、最後には細川藤賢の家来下津権内に首を取られた。
sen.e: Although Tomomichi IWANARI fought bravely, he was eventually decapitated by Gonnai SHIMOZU, a retainer of Fujikata HOSOKAWA.
Although Tomomichi IWANARI fought bravely, he was eventually decapitated by Gonnai SHIMOZU, a retainer of Fujikata HOSOKAWA.
Although Tomomichi IWANARI fought bravely, he was eventually decapitated by Gonnai SHIMOZU, a retainer of Fujikata HOSOKAWA.

sen.j: その首は近江国の高島町 (滋賀県)に出軍中の織田信長の元に届けられ、比類なき働きに嘉賞し着ていた胴衣をかけたと『信長公記』には記されている。
sen.e: His head was brought to Nobunaga ODA who was in the field in Takashima-cho (Shiga Prefecture) of Omi Province and "Shincho koki" (Biography of the Warlord Oda Nobunaga) described that Nobunaga praised Gonnai SHIMOZU for his unparalleled actions and covered him with the padded, sleeveless undergarment Nobunaga wore.

His head was brought to Nobunaga ODA who was in the field in Takashima-cho (Shiga Prefecture) of Omi Province and "Shincho koki" (Biography of the Warlord Oda Nobunaga) described that Nobunaga praised Gonnai SHIMOZU for his unparalleled actions and covered him with the padded, sleeveless undergarment Nobunaga wore.

His head was brought to Nobunaga ODA who was in the field in Takashima-cho (Shiga Prefecture) of Omi Province and "Shincho koki" (Biography of the Warlord Oda Nobunaga) described that Nobunaga praised Gonnai SHIMOZU for his unparalleled actions and covered him with the padded, sleeveless undergarment Nobunaga wore.

sen.j: 天正10年（1582年）6月本能寺の変の後、『兼見卿記』によると明智光秀が淀古城を改修したと記録され、羽柴秀吉と明智光秀の山崎の戦いでも利用された。
sen.e: Kanemi Kyoki (Kanemi's Diary) recorded that after the Honnoji Incident in June 1582 Mitsuhide AKECHI repaired the Yodo kojo Castle, and it was also used in the Battle of Yamasaki between Hideyoshi HASHIBA and Mitsuhide AKECHI.

Kanemi Kyoki (Kanemi's Diary) recorded that after the Honnoji Incident in June 1582 Mitsuhide AKECHI repaired Yodo kojo Castle, and it was also used in the Battle of Yamasaki between Hideyoshi HASHIBA and Mitsuhide AKECHI.

According to "Kanemi Kyoki (Kanemi's Diary)", after the Honnoji Incident in June 1582, Mitsuhide AKECHI repaired Yodo kojo Castle, and it was also used in the Battle of Yamasaki War between Hideyoshi HASHIBA and Mitsuhide AKECHI.
sen.cmt: 一部、翻訳を変更しました。

sen.j: 豊臣秀吉の天下となってからは、天正17年（1589年）3月羽柴秀長が淀古城が改修し、豊臣秀吉が側室茶々に与えたものであり産所とする為であった。
sen.e: After Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI came into power, Hidenaga HASHIBA repaired the Yodo kojo Castle in March 1589, which Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI gave to his concubine, Chacha for her maternity room.
After Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI came into power, Hidenaga HASHIBA repaired Yodo kojo Castle in March 1589, which Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI gave to his concubine, Chacha for her maternity room.
After Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI came into power, Hidenaga HASHIBA repaired Yodo kojo Castle in April 1589, which Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI gave to his concubine, Chacha for her maternity room.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に変更しました。

sen.j: これにより茶々は「淀殿」と呼ばれるようになる。
sen.e: Due to this fact, Chacha came to be called 'Yodo-dono' (Lady Yodo).
Due to this fact, Chacha came to be called 'Yodo-dono' (Lady Yodo).
Due to this fact, Chacha came to be called 'Yodo-dono' (Lady Yodo).

sen.j: この城で淀殿秀吉の側室に鶴丸が産まれるが1591年に死去してしまった。
sen.e: In this castle, Yodo-dono, Hideyoshi's concubine gave birth to a baby, who immediately died.
sen.cmt: 「側室にが産まれるが」を「側室に子供が産まれるが」として、また、「産まれるがに死去してしまった」を「産まれるが直ぐに死去してしまった」として訳しました。
sen.e: In this castle, Yodo-dono, Hideyoshi's concubine gave birth to a baby, who immediately died.
In this castle, Yodo-dono, Hideyoshi's concubine gave birth to a baby, Tsurumaru who immediately died in 1591.
sen.cmt: ウェブを参考に本文を補って(赤字）訳しました。

sen.j: 鶴丸が死亡し羽柴秀次が養子となるが、豊臣秀頼が産まれると羽柴秀次と軋轢が生じ、この城の最後の城主であった木村常陸介も連座、城も廃城となる。
sen.e: Tsurumaru died and Hidetsugu HASHIBA was adopted, but when Hideyori TOYOTOMI was born, a conflict started with Hidetsugu HASHIBA, and Hitachi no suke KIMURA, the last castellan of this castle was implicated and the castle was deserted.

Tsurumaru died and Hidetsugu HASHIBA was adopted, but when Hideyori TOYOTOMI was born, a conflict started with Hidetsugu HASHIBA, and Hitachi no suke KIMURA, the last castellan of this castle was implicated and the castle was deserted.

Tsurumaru died and Hidetsugu HASHIBA was adopted, but when Hideyori TOYOTOMI was born, a conflict started with Hidetsugu HASHIBA, and Hitachi no suke KIMURA, the last castellan of this castle was implicated and the castle was deserted.

sen.j: 1595年（文禄4年）の事であった。
sen.cmt: 原文に欠落があり、翻訳不可と考えます。
sen.e: It was happened in 1595.
sen.cmt: 年号をウェブから補って訳しました（本文は赤字）。

tit.e: Area surrounded by the castle wall
Area surrounded by the castle wall
Area surrounded by the castle wall

sen.j: 淀古城は水陸交通の要街として槇島城と並ぶ山城国洛南の二大軍事拠点の一つであった。
sen.e: The Yodo kojo Castle was an important center for water and land transportation and one of the two major points of strategic importance in Rakunan of the Yamashiro Province ranking with the Makishima-jo Castle.
Yodo kojo Castle was an important center for water and land transportation and one of the two major points of strategic importance in Rakunan of Yamashiro Province, ranking with Makishima-jo Castle.
Yodo kojo Castle was an important center for water and land transportation and one of the two major points of strategic importance in Rakunan of Yamashiro Province, ranking with Makishima-jo Castle.

sen.j: また西国方面の海産物の集荷市場、魚市場があり、対岸の大山崎町と並んで京都の要害で、淀古城の東側には現在は存在していない巨椋池が広がっていたと思われている。
sen.e: Having a consolidating area for seafoods from Saigoku (western provinces) and a fish market, it was a strategic point of Kyoto ranking with Oyamazaki-cho on the opposite shore and an expanse of now-nonexistent Ogura-ike Pond is thought to have been on the east side of the Yodo kojo Castle.

Having a consolidating area for seafoods from Saigoku (western provinces) and a fish market, it was a strategic point of Kyoto ranking with Oyamazaki-cho on the opposite shore and the expanse of now-non-existent Ogura-ike Pond is thought to have been on the east side of Yodo kojo Castle.

Having a consolidating area for seafood from Saigoku (western provinces) and a fish market, it was a strategic point of Kyoto ranking with Oyamazaki-cho on the opposite shore and the expanse of now-non-existent Ogura-ike Pond is thought to have been on the east side of Yodo kojo Castle.

sen.j: 1890年（明治23年）の『測量の仮製図』によると、堀跡と納所集落の東側に土塁が記載されていたが、現在跡地には、宅地化、耕作地、納所小学校が建っており、唯一妙教寺 (伏見区)に石碑が建つのみで、北城堀や小字城堀という地名が僅かにその面影を留めている。
sen.e: An earthwork was on the "Tentative map by survey" at the east side of the moat ruin and the Noso village, but on the former site today, there are residential land, cultivated land and the Noso Elementary School, and only the stone monument existing at Myokyo-ji Temple (Fushimi Ward), geographical names such as Kitashirobori and Koazashirobori slightly recall the flavor of the castle..
sen.cmt: 「の『測量の仮製図』によると」の前が欠落していますが、下記サイトから推測すれ「参謀本部」が出典でしょうか。「"Tentative map by survey"」は、仮訳です。「http://uenishi01.at.infoseek.co.jp/j664sanbou.html 「妙教寺」（みょうきょうじ）は、下記サイトより。 http://kyotokankou.web.fc2.com/0068tobahusiminotatakaitoba.html
sen.e: An earthwork was on the "Tentative map by survey" at the east side of the moat ruin and the Noso village, but on the former site today, there is residential land, cultivated land and the Noso Elementary School, and only the stone monument existing at Myokyo-ji Temple (Fushimi Ward), geographical names such as Kitashirobori and Koazashirobori slightly recall the flavor of the castle..

According to "Tentative map by survey" in 1890, an earthwork was on the at the east side of the moat ruin and the Noso village, but on the former site today, there is residential land, cultivated land and the Noso Elementary School, and only the stone monument existing at Myokyo-ji Temple (Fushimi Ward), geographical names such as Kitashirobori and Koazashirobori slightly recall the flavor of the castle.
sen.cmt: ウェブを参考に本文を補って(赤字）訳しました（一部、変更）。

sen.j: 淀古城については数多い歴史があるが、近隣の淀城と違って城郭は不明な点が多い。
sen.e: The Yodo kojo Castle are full of historic events, but lack of information on the castle construction differently from the Yodo-jo Castle nearby.
The Yodo kojo Castle is full of historic events, but there is a lack of information on castle construction different from the nearby Yodo-jo Castle.
The Yodo kojo Castle is full of historic events, but there is a lack of information on castle construction unlike with the nearby Yodo-jo Castle.
sen.cmt: different fromをunlike withに変更しました。

sen.j: 天守に関しても詳細は不明であるが、『駒井日記』には淀古城の天守が存在していた事が記載されている。
sen.e: The details of the Tenshu (main keep or tower of a castle) are unknown, but the Komai nikki (diary of Shigekatsu KOMAI) described the existence of Tenshu in the Yodo kojo Castle.
The details of the Tenshu (main keep or tower of a castle) are unknown, but the Komai nikki (diary of Shigekatsu KOMAI) described the existence of Tenshu in Yodo kojo Castle.
The details of the Tenshu (main keep or tower of a castle) are unknown, but the "Komai nikki" (diary of Shigekatsu KOMAI) described the existence of Tenshu in Yodo kojo Castle.

sen.j: 淀古城が廃城の後、多くの資材は伏見城建築に使用されたようである。
sen.e: After the Yodo kojo Castle was deserted, many of its materials seemed to be used for the construction of the Fushimi Castle.
After Yodo kojo Castle was deserted, many of its materials appear to have been used for construction of Fushimi Castle.
After Yodo kojo Castle was deserted, many of its materials appear to have been used for construction of Fushimi-jo Castle.

sen.j: またその後淀城築城の際にはその伏見城から資材が流用された。
sen.e: Afterward, for the construction of Yodo-jo Castle, materials were diverted from the Fushimi Castle.
Afterwards, for the construction of Yodo-jo Castle, materials were diverted from Fushimi Castle.
Afterwards, for the construction of Yodo-jo Castle, materials were diverted from Fushimi-jo Castle.
sen.cmt: Fushimiを Fushimi-joに変更しました。

sen.j: 京滋バイパス 久御山淀インターチェンジ → 京都府道15号宇治淀線 → 京都府道126号新町淀停車場線 → 京都府道・大阪府道13号京都守口線

Keiji Bypass Kumiyama Yodo Interchange → Kyoto prefectural road No.15, Uji Yodo Route → Kyoto prefectural road No.126, Shinmachi Teishajo-sen →Kyoto-Moriguchi-sen, Kyoto Fudo 13 Go and Osaka Fudo 13 Go (Kyoto/Osaka Prefectural Road 13)

Keiji Bypass Kumiyama Yodo Interchange → Kyoto prefectural road No.15, Uji Yodo Route → Kyoto prefectural road No.126, Shinmachi Teishajo-line →Kyoto-Moriguchi-line, Kyoto Fudo 13 Go and Osaka Fudo 13 Go (Kyoto/Osaka Prefectural Road No.13)
